XML:
<ce:table xmlns:ce="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd" xmlns="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/ja/dtd" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:sa="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/struct-aff/dtd" xmlns:sb="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/struct-bib/dtd" id="tbl0001" rowsep="0" colsep="0" frame="topbot">
<ce:label>TABLE 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0009">
<ce:simple-para id="spara009">Summary of Guidelines for Imaging of Nonfibrotic Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:alt-text id="alt0009" role="short">TABLE 1:</ce:alt-text>
<tgroup cols="3">
<colspec colnum="1" colname="col1" align="left"/>
<colspec colnum="2" colname="col2" align="left"/>
<colspec colnum="3" colname="col3" align="left"/>
<tbody>
<row>
<entry id="en0001" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top"/>
<entry id="en0002" align="left" namest="col2" nameend="col3" role="colgroup" valign="top"><ce:bold>Typical HP</ce:bold></entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0003" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top"/>
<entry id="en0004" colname="col2" valign="top">ATS/JRS/ALAT</entry>
<entry id="en0005" colname="col3" valign="top">ACCP</entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0006" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Description</entry>
<entry id="en0007" colname="col2" valign="top">Requires at least one finding of parenchymal disease AND at least one finding of small airway disease, both in a diffuse distribution.</entry>
<entry id="en0008" colname="col3" valign="top">Requires any of the following findings AND a lack of features suggesting an alternative diagnosis:</entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0009" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Findings</entry>
<entry id="en0010" colname="col2" valign="top">Parenchymal:<ce:list id="celist0001">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0001"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0025">GGO</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0002"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0026">Mosaic attenuation</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Small airway:<ce:list id="celist0002">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0003"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0027">Ill-defined, centrilobular nodules</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0004"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0028">Air trapping</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
<entry id="en0011" colname="col3" valign="top">
<ce:list id="celist0003">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0005"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0029">Profuse poorly defined centrilobular nodules</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0006"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0030">Inspiratory mosaic attenuation with three-density sign</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0007"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0031">Inspiratory mosaic attenuation and air trapping associated with centrilobular nodules</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0012" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top"/>
<entry id="en0013" align="left" namest="col2" nameend="col3" role="colgroup" valign="top"><ce:bold>Compatible with HP</ce:bold></entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0014" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top"/>
<entry id="en0015" colname="col2" valign="top">ATS/JRS/ALAT</entry>
<entry id="en0016" colname="col3" valign="top">ACCP</entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0017" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Description</entry>
<entry id="en0018" colname="col2" valign="top">Requires any of the following findings in any of the following distributions:</entry>
<entry id="en0019" colname="col3" valign="top">Requires any of the following findings AND a lack of features suggesting an alternative diagnosis:</entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0020" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Findings</entry>
<entry id="en0021" colname="col2" valign="top">Parenchymal:<ce:list id="celist0004">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0008"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0032">Uniform and subtle GGO</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0009"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0033">Airspace consolidation</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0010"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0034">Lung cysts</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Craniocaudal distribution:<ce:list id="celist0005">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0011"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0035">Diffuse</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0012"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0036">Lower lobe predominance</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Axial distribution:<ce:list id="celist0006">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0013"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0037">Diffuse</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0014"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0038">Peribronchovascular</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
<entry id="en0022" colname="col3" valign="top">
<ce:list id="celist0007">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0015"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0039">Centrilobular ground-glass attenuation nodules that are not profuse or diffuse, and not associated with mosaic attenuation or air trapping</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0016"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0040">Patchy or diffuse GGO</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0017"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0041">Mosaic attenuation and air trapping without centrilobular nodules or GGO</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
</row>
</tbody>
</tgroup>
<ce:legend>
<ce:simple-para id="spara010"><ce:italic>Definitions of abbreviations: HP = hypersensitivity pneumonitis; ATS/JRS/ALAT = American Thoracic Society, Japanese Respiratory Society, and Asociación Latinoamericana de Tórax; ACCP = American College of Chest Physicians; GGO = ground glass opacity</ce:italic></ce:simple-para>
</ce:legend>
</ce:table>

  <ce:italic>Definitions of abbreviations: HP = hypersensitivity pneumonitis; ATS/JRS/ALAT = American Thoracic Society, Japanese Respiratory Society, and Asociación Latinoamericana de Tórax; ACCP = American College of Chest Physicians; GGO = ground glass opacity</ce:italic>

XML:
<ce:table xmlns:ce="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd" xmlns="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/ja/dtd" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:sa="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/struct-aff/dtd" xmlns:sb="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/struct-bib/dtd" id="tbl0002" rowsep="0" colsep="0" frame="topbot">
<ce:label>TABLE 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0010">
<ce:simple-para id="spara011">Summary of Guidelines for Imaging of Fibrotic Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:alt-text id="alt0010" role="short">TABLE 2:</ce:alt-text>
<tgroup cols="3">
<colspec colnum="1" colname="col1" align="left"/>
<colspec colnum="2" colname="col2" align="left"/>
<colspec colnum="3" colname="col3" align="left"/>
<tbody>
<row>
<entry id="en0023" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top"/>
<entry id="en0024" align="left" namest="col2" nameend="col3" role="colgroup" valign="top"><ce:bold>Typical HP</ce:bold></entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0025" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top"/>
<entry id="en0026" colname="col2" valign="top">ATS/JRS/ALAT</entry>
<entry id="en0027" colname="col3" valign="top">ACCP</entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0028" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Description</entry>
<entry id="en0029" colname="col2" valign="top">Requires one of the following patterns of lung fibrosis in one of the listed distributions AND at least one finding of small airway disease:</entry>
<entry id="en0030" colname="col3" valign="top">Requires signs of fibrosis with either of the following findings AND a lack of features suggesting an alternative diagnosis:</entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0031" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Findings</entry>
<entry id="en0032" colname="col2" valign="top">Pattern of fibrosis:<ce:list id="celist0008">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0018"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0043">Irregular linear opacities/coarse reticulation with lung distortion</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0019"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0044">Traction bronchiectasis and honeycombing (present but do not predominate)</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Distribution of fibrosis:<ce:list id="celist0009">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0020"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0045">Random both axially and craniocaudally</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0021"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0046">Mid lung zone predominant</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0022"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0047">Relatively spared in the lower lungs</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Small airways:<ce:list id="celist0010">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0023"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0048">Ill-defined centrilobular nodules and/or GGO</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0024"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0049">Mosaic attenuation, three-density pattern, and/or air trapping</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
<entry id="en0033" colname="col3" valign="top">
<ce:list id="celist0011">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0025"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0050">Profuse poorly defined centrilobular ground-glass attenuation nodules affecting all lung zones</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0026"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0051">Inspiratory mosaic attenuation with three-density sign</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0034" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top"/>
<entry id="en0035" align="left" namest="col2" nameend="col3" role="colgroup" valign="top"><ce:bold>Compatible with HP</ce:bold></entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0036" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top"/>
<entry id="en0037" colname="col2" valign="top">ATS/JRS/ALAT</entry>
<entry id="en0038" colname="col3" valign="top">ACCP</entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0039" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Description</entry>
<entry id="en0040" colname="col2" valign="top">Requires one of the following variant patterns of fibrosis and/or one of the following variant distributions of fibrosis AND at least one finding of small airway disease:</entry>
<entry id="en0041" colname="col3" valign="top">Requires signs of fibrosis with either of the following findings AND a lack of features suggesting an alternative diagnosis:</entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0042" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Findings</entry>
<entry id="en0043" colname="col2" valign="top">Pattern of fibrosis:<ce:list id="celist0012">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0027"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0052">UIP pattern</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0028"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0053">Extensive GGO with subtle superimposed features of fibrosis</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Distribution of fibrosis:<ce:list id="celist0013">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0029"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0054">Axial: peribronchovascular or subpleural</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0030"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0055">Craniocaudal: Upper lung</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Small airways:<ce:list id="celist0014">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0031"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0056">Ill-defined centrilobular nodules and/or GGO</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0032"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0057">Mosaic attenuation, three-density pattern, and/or air trapping</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
<entry id="en0044" colname="col3" valign="top">
<ce:list id="celist0015">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0033"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0058">Patchy or diffuse GGO</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0034"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0059">Patchy, nonprofuse centrilobular nodules</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0035"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0060">Mosaic attenuation and air trapping that do not meet the criteria for fibrotic HP</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0045" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top"/>
<entry id="en0046" align="left" namest="col2" nameend="col3" role="colgroup" valign="top"><ce:bold>Indeterminate for HP</ce:bold></entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0047" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top"/>
<entry id="en0048" colname="col2" valign="top">ATS/JRS/ALAT</entry>
<entry id="en0049" colname="col3" valign="top">ACCP</entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0050" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Description & Findings</entry>
<entry id="en0051" colname="col2" valign="top">Requires a pattern of fibrosis without other findings suggestive of HP</entry>
<entry id="en0052" colname="col3" valign="top">Requires signs of fibrosis without other features suggestive of HP</entry>
</row>
</tbody>
</tgroup>
<ce:legend>
<ce:simple-para id="spara012"><ce:italic>Definitions of abbreviations: HP = hypersensitivity pneumonitis; ATS/JRS/ALAT = American Thoracic Society, Japanese Respiratory Society, and Asociación Latinoamericana de Tórax; ACCP = American College of Chest Physicians; GGO = ground glass opacity; UIP = usual interstitial pneumonia</ce:italic></ce:simple-para>
</ce:legend>
</ce:table>

<ce:table xmlns:ce="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd" xmlns="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/ja/dtd" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:sa="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/struct-aff/dtd" xmlns:sb="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/struct-bib/dtd" id="tbl0003" rowsep="0" colsep="0" frame="topbot">
<ce:label>TABLE 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0011">
<ce:simple-para id="spara013">Definition and Diagnostic Criteria for Acute Exacerbation of Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:alt-text id="alt0011" role="short">TABLE 3:</ce:alt-text>
<tgroup cols="2">
<colspec colnum="1" colname="col1" align="left"/>
<colspec colnum="2" colname="col2" align="left"/>
<tbody>
<row>
<entry id="en0053" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Definition</entry>
<entry id="en0054" colname="col2" valign="top">An acute, clinically significant respiratory deterioration characterized by evidence of new widespread alveolar abnormality</entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0055" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Diagnostic Criteria</entry>
<entry id="en0056" colname="col2" valign="top">
<ce:list id="celist0016">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0036"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0062">Previous or concurrent diagnosis of IPF</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0037"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0063">Acute worsening or development of dyspnea typically < 1 month duration</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0038"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0064">CT with new bilateral GGO and/or consolidation superimposed on a background consistent with UIP pattern</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0039"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0065">Deterioration not fully explained by cardiac failure or fluid overload</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
</row>
</tbody>
</tgroup>
<ce:legend>
<ce:simple-para id="spara014"><ce:italic>Definitions of abbreviations: IPF = Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis; GGO = ground glass opacity; UIP = Usual interstitial pneumonia</ce:italic></ce:simple-para>
</ce:legend>
</ce:table>

  <ce:italic>Definitions of abbreviations: IPF = Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis; GGO = ground glass opacity; UIP = Usual interstitial pneumonia</ce:italic>

XML:
<ce:table xmlns:ce="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd" xmlns="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/ja/dtd" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:sa="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/struct-aff/dtd" xmlns:sb="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/struct-bib/dtd" id="tbl0004" rowsep="0" colsep="0" frame="topbot">
<ce:label>TABLE 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption id="cap0012">
<ce:simple-para id="spara015">Comparison of Select Imaging Criteria for Usual Interstitial Pneumonia and Fibrotic Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:alt-text id="alt0012" role="short">TABLE 4:</ce:alt-text>
<tgroup cols="3">
<colspec colnum="1" colname="col1" align="left"/>
<colspec colnum="2" colname="col2" align="left"/>
<colspec colnum="3" colname="col3" align="left"/>
<tbody>
<row>
<entry id="en0057" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top"/>
<entry id="en0058" colname="col2" valign="top">UIP</entry>
<entry id="en0059" colname="col3" valign="top">Fibrotic HP</entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0060" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Fibrosis Features</entry>
<entry id="en0061" colname="col2" valign="top">Typical UIP:<ce:list id="celist0017">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0040"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0067">Honeycombing</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0041"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0068">± Traction bronchiectasis or bronchiolectasis</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Probable UIP:<ce:list id="celist0018">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0042"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0069">Reticular pattern with peripheral traction bronchiectasis or bronchiolectasis</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
<entry id="en0062" colname="col3" valign="top">Typical HP:<ce:list id="celist0019">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0043"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0070">Irregular linear opacities/coarse reticulation with lung distortion</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0044"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0071">± Traction bronchiectasis and honeycombing (does not predominate)</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Compatible with HP:<ce:list id="celist0020">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0045"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0072">UIP pattern</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0046"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0073">Subtle features of fibrosis with extensive superimposed GGO</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0063" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Fibrosis Distribution</entry>
<entry id="en0064" colname="col2" valign="top">Typical UIP:<ce:list id="celist0021">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0047"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0074">Axial: Subpleural predominant, often heterogeneous</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0048"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0075">Craniocaudal: Basal predominant, often heterogeneous</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Probable UIP:<ce:list id="celist0022">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0049"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0076">Axial: Subpleural predominant, often heterogeneous</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0050"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0077">Craniocaudal: Basal predominant, often heterogeneous</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
<entry id="en0065" colname="col3" valign="top">Typical HP:<ce:list id="celist0023">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0051"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0078">Axial: Random</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0052"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0079">Craniocaudal: Random, mid lung predominant, or relative basal sparing</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Compatible with HP:<ce:list id="celist0024">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0053"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0080">Axial: UIP pattern or peribronchovascular + subpleural</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0054"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0081">Craniocaudal: UIP pattern or upper lung predominant</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0066" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Superimposed Nonfibrotic Features</entry>
<entry id="en0067" colname="col2" valign="top">Typical UIP:<ce:list id="celist0025">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0055"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0082">None</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Probable UIP:<ce:list id="celist0026">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0056"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0083">± Mild GGO</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
<entry id="en0068" colname="col3" valign="top">Typical HP:<ce:list id="celist0027">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0057"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0084">Ill-defined centrilobular nodules and/or GGO*†</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0058"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0085">Mosaic attenuation*†</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0059"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0086">Three-density pattern*†</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0060"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0087">Air trapping*</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Compatible with HP:<ce:list id="celist0028">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0061"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0088">Ill-defined centrilobular nodules*†</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0062"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0089">Three-density pattern*</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0063"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0090">Air trapping*†</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0064"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0091">Mosaic attenuation†</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
</row>
<row>
<entry id="en0069" colname="col1" role="rowhead" valign="top">Findings Suggestive of Alternative Diagnosis</entry>
<entry id="en0070" colname="col2" valign="top">Features:<ce:list id="celist0029">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0065"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0092">Cysts</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0066"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0093">Marked mosaic attenuation</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0067"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0094">Predominant GGO</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0068"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0095">Profuse micronodules</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0069"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0096">Centrilobular nodules</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0070"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0097">Nodules (other than described above)</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0071"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0098">Consolidation</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list>Distribution:<ce:list id="celist0030">
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0072"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0099">Peribronchovascular</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0073"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0100">Perilymphatic</ce:para></ce:list-item>
<ce:list-item id="celistitem0074"><ce:label>•</ce:label><ce:para id="para0101">Upper or mid lung</ce:para></ce:list-item>
</ce:list></entry>
<entry id="en0071" colname="col3" valign="top">N/A. In the absence of features suggestive of HP, fibrotic interstitial lung disease of type and distribution could still represent fibrotic HP (“Indeterminate for HP” category)</entry>
</row>
</tbody>
</tgroup>
<ce:legend>
<ce:simple-para id="spara016"><ce:italic>* ATS/JRS/ALAT guidelines</ce:italic></ce:simple-para>
<ce:simple-para id="spara017"><ce:italic>† ACCP guidelines</ce:italic></ce:simple-para>
<ce:simple-para id="spara018"><ce:italic>Criteria for “Indeterminate for UIP” and “Indeterminate for HP” categories were intentionally omitted for clarity and brevity</ce:italic></ce:simple-para>
<ce:simple-para id="spara019"><ce:italic>Definitions of abbreviations: UIP = Usual interstitial pneumonia; HP = Hypersensitivity pneumonitis; GGO = Ground-glass opacity</ce:italic></ce:simple-para>
</ce:legend>

<ce:simple-para id="spara015"><ce:sup>3</ce:sup>PolyPhen-2 score ranges from 0.0 to 1.0. Variants with scores of 0.0 are predicted to be benign. Values closer to 1.0 are more confidently predicted to be deleterious</ce:simple-para>
<ce:simple-para id="spara016"><ce:sup>4</ce:sup>Column “ChIP Data” listed the most frequently bond transcriptional factor (TF) and/or subunit of transcriptional machinery for the variant coordinate Numbers in parenthesis are # of CHIP-seq data sets showing peak of listed TF or subunit / total # of CHIP-seq data sets with peak at the variant coordinate</ce:simple-para>
<ce:simple-para id="spara017"><ce:sup>5</ce:sup>RegulomeDB rank 4 represents “TF binding + DNase peak” as supporting data for the variant coordinate</ce:simple-para>
<ce:simple-para id="spara018"><ce:sup>6</ce:sup>RegulomeDB rank 2b represents “TF binding + any motif + DNase Footprint + DNase peak” as supporting data for the variant coordinate</ce:simple-para>
<ce:simple-para id="spara019"><ce:sup>7</ce:sup>EZH2, enhancer of zeste homolog 2, is a histone-lysine N-methyltransferase enzyme</ce:simple-para>
<ce:simple-para id="spara020"><ce:sup>8</ce:sup>POLR2A, RNA polymerase II subunit A, is the largest subunit of RNA polymerase II - the polymerase responsible for synthesizing messenger RNA in eukaryotes</ce:simple-para>

<ce:sections xmlns:ce="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/dtd" xmlns="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/ja/dtd" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:sa="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/struct-aff/dtd" xmlns:sb="http://www.elsevier.com/xml/common/struct-bib/dtd">
<ce:section id="sec0001" role="introduction">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0003">INTRODUCTION</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0002">Any breast pathology warrants evaluation using imaging techniques and tissue sampling to determine the underlying etiology and rule out any evidence of malignancy. In certain circumstances, mammography (MG) features are characteristic and do not indicate further intervention, for example, intramammary lymph node, lipoma, and breast hamartoma. In contrast, any deviation from benign features requires evaluation with adjunct modalities and image-guided tissue sampling. To facilitate communication with physicians and pathologists, ACR has developed descriptors and classifications within the BIRADS (American College of Radiology – Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System) lexicon.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0006" refid="bib0001"><ce:sup>1</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> The definitely benign entities with essentially 0% chance of malignancy have been placed under BIRADS category 2 and are not to be touched. However, an overlap between benign and malignant features is often seen due to the atypical and overlapping appearances of breast masses; therefore, malignant lesions can sometimes be categorized as BI-RADS 3 (probably benign with less than or equal to 2% chance of malignancy) and benign lesions as 4C (50-95% chance of malignancy). Benign pathologies, such as inflammatory changes and vascular malformations, can mimic the appearance of malignancies; therefore, they can be classified as either BI-RADS 4a (2-10% malignant possibility) or 4B (10-50% probability), or 5 (>95% probability of malignancy). Thus, biopsy is indicated in all these patients for confirmation.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0007" refid="bib0002"><ce:sup>2</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> The caveat with histopathological evaluation lies in the provision and evaluation of the tissue cores provided to the pathologist, in contrast to the radiologist, who can visualize the entire tumor or breast disease on MG, USG, or MRI. Hence, it is imperative to obtain the rad-path correlation in each individual and achieve clinic-radio-pathological concordance before commencing the treatment protocol. Any discordant result should be re-evaluated for the need for additional imaging assessment or repeat biopsy on a patient-to-patient basis, and such decisions should be made in multidisciplinary team (MDT) meetings.</ce:para>
<ce:para id="para0003">The ‘discordant benign’ result refers to benign findings on biopsy for a lesion which was considered suspicious on radiology, and ‘discordant malignant’would mean malignancy on biopsy for a lesion which was thought to have low suspicion for malignancy on imaging.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0008" refid="bib0003"><ce:sup>3</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> On the other hand, rare malignancies and rare benign pathologies, even if concordant on histopathology, benefit from multidepartment discussions for optimal management.</ce:para>
<ce:para id="para0004">Considering the significant impact of rad-path correlation on patient management, this article aims to illustrate various entities that demonstrate discordant results, highlighting key features that can aid radiologists in accurately approaching breast diseases and achieving rad-path correlation during MDT discussions.</ce:para>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0002">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0004">INFLAMMATORY CONDITIONS</ce:section-title>
<ce:section id="sec0003">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0005">Idiopathic granulomatous mastitis</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0005">First recognized in the early 1970s, idiopathic granulomatous mastitis (IGM) is a benign inflammatory disease seen in childbearing and parous premenopausal women with a history of breastfeeding.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0009" refid="bib0004"><ce:sup>4</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Histologically, these lesions are characterized by non-caseating granulomas comprised of epithelioid cells, Langhans giant cells, and lymphocytes, with formation of microabscesses, with no evidence of microorganisms.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0010" refid="bib0005"><ce:sup>5</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Patients often present with unilateral painful retro-areolar swelling, with skin erythema and induration. The exact etiology is unknown, but predisposing factors include pregnancy, lactation, hyperprolactinemia, oral contraceptives, alpha–1–antitrypsin deficiency, diabetes, smoking, and autoimmune disease. It has been postulated that this is caused by the flow of ductal luminal secretions into the lobular stroma following injury to the ductal epithelium, which in turn stimulates a cascade of inflammatory and granulomatous responses.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0011" refid="bib0004"><ce:sup>4</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref><ce:sup>,</ce:sup><ce:cross-ref id="crf0012" refid="bib0007"><ce:sup>7</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> On mammography (MG), they are seen as focal asymmetries or irregular or obscured masses, with axillary adenopathy and skin changes that often mimic breast malignancy<ce:cross-ref id="crf0013" refid="bib0008"><ce:sup>8</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> (<ce:cross-ref id="crf0014" refid="fig0001">Figure 1</ce:cross-ref><ce:float-anchor refid="fig0001"/>). Calcifications are rarely observed. Ultrasound (US) features include irregular parallel hypoechoic masses with tubular extension or fluid-tracking channels, which could help the radiologist raise suspicion of mastitis over malignancy.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0015" refid="bib0007"><ce:sup>7</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> These masses or channels insinuate the breast parenchyma along Cooper’s ligament, with perilesional hypervascularity, fluid collections, or abscess formation with or without sinus tracts<ce:cross-ref id="crf0016" refid="bib0009"><ce:sup>9</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> (<ce:cross-ref id="crf0017" refid="fig0001">Figure 1</ce:cross-ref>). Heterogeneous or rim enhancement along the fluid collection and regional non-mass enhancement (NME) can be seen in the involved breast parenchyma on MRI. The imaging features mimic inflammatory breast carcinoma, which must be excluded on biopsy. Features such as unilateral breast enlargement, clinically palpable axillary lymphadenopathy, extensive skin edema, trabecular thickening involving over one-third of the breast with associated rapid enhancement, and T2 hyperintense signals extending to the chest wall in older age groups suggest IBC over IGM<ce:cross-ref id="crf0018" refid="bib0007"><ce:sup>7</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>. Elastography can also be a useful adjunct, as the mean strain elastography values are significantly lower in IGM compared to invasive ductal carcinoma.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0019" refid="bib0010"><ce:sup>10</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>
</ce:para>
</ce:section>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0004">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0006">Diabetic mastopathy</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0006">They are rare palpable painless masses found in about 1 – 13 % of patients with long-standing insulin-dependent diabetes.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0020" refid="bib0011"><ce:sup>11</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Lymphocytic infiltration and fibrosis in this condition are thought to be due to the accumulation of hyperglycemia-induced glycosylated end products or insulin itself.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0021" refid="bib0012"><ce:sup>12</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Diabetic mastopathy can be seen on MG as a mass with lobulated or spiculated margins. In contrast, on USG, these lesions can be seen as irregular hetero-echoic masses with posterior shadowing that often get categorized as BI-RADS 4B or 4C (<ce:cross-ref id="crf0022" refid="fig0002">Figure 2</ce:cross-ref><ce:float-anchor refid="fig0002"/>). Appropriate and adequate clinical history may help achieve rad-path concordance. MRI also shows variable appearance and enhancement on conventional and post-contrast sequences. Being indistinguishable from breast malignancies by imaging, histopathological confirmation is often required to establish a diagnosis. They can be bilateral and have a high (about 60%) chance of recurrence post-surgical excision; hence, excision biopsy is not preferred.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0023" refid="bib0012"><ce:sup>12</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>
</ce:para>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0005">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0007">Duct ectasia and periductal mastitis</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0007">Duct ectasia is defined as dilatation of the lactiferous ducts measuring more than 2 mm or the ampullary portion over 3 mm in calibre.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0024" refid="bib0013"><ce:sup>13</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> The dilated ducts may show anechoic lumen and may be asymptomatic. Benign ductal dilatation is usually observed with advancing age and is bilateral, symmetric, and thought to be due to normal involution or hormonal factors. Any leak of ductal secretions due to epithelial damage causes periductal inflammation and further infection. Subareolar mastitis is common in middle-aged women, with extrinsic insults such as smoking-induced squamous metaplasia, duct block, and inflammatory changes. Peripheral mastitis and breast abscess due to Staphylococcus aureus occur in older women, with risk factors of diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, or pre-existing breast cysts. Asymmetric peripheral duct dilatation, duct irregularity, associated hypoechoic soft tissue masses or microcalcifications, and focal thickening of the duct wall are features that increase the possibility of an associated malignancy.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0025" refid="bib0014"><ce:sup>14</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Hence, it becomes crucial to identify any intraluminal contents, especially in solitary dilated ducts or in patients presenting with nipple discharge. US serves as the imaging modality of choice for these patients because MG may or may not show tubular serpentine structures converging on the nipple-areola complex. In contrast, US can also show intraductal echogenic debris, periductal increased vascularity and inflammation, oval solid masses with vascularity (papillomas), or associated malignant masses<ce:cross-ref id="crf0026" refid="bib0013"><ce:sup>13</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> (<ce:cross-ref id="crf0027" refid="fig0003">Figure 3</ce:cross-ref><ce:float-anchor refid="fig0003"/>). They are soft on shear wave elastography and show blue – green – red trilaminar pattern on strain elastography corresponding to the cystic nature of the mass.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0028" refid="bib0015"><ce:sup>15</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> MRI can show areas of mass or non-mass enhancement corresponding to mastitis, ductal dilatation, prominent vessels, abnormal nipple configuration, skin thickening, edema and abscesses, which can rarely turn into ductal fistulas.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0029" refid="bib0016"><ce:sup>16</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>
</ce:para>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0006">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0008">Sclerosing lesions of the breast</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0008">They are benign proliferation of acini and myoepithelium followed by stromal fibrosis in the terminal ductal lobular unit, which can mimic as well as increase the risk of associated malignancy. They are more often non-palpable masses incidentally detected on imaging in premenopausal women. Isolated sclerosing adenosis has an incidence of about 3%.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0030" refid="bib0017"><ce:sup>17</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> They can appear as masses, asymmetries, or focal architectural distortion with microcalcifications, particularly in clusters. Ultrasound can show heteroechoic areas, dense posterior acoustic shadowing, or actual masses with or without visible calcifications.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0031" refid="bib0018"><ce:sup>18</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Radial scar or complex sclerosing lesion is a distinct entity which can produce similar appearances like spiculated masses or architectural distortion, often with a central radiolucent area (<ce:cross-ref id="crf0032" refid="fig0004">Figure 4</ce:cross-ref><ce:float-anchor refid="fig0004"/>). Elastography is not helpful, as it may also show stiffness similar to invasive breast carcinoma. On MRI, they appear as masses, non-mass enhancement, or enhancing foci with benign persistent kinetic curves in 50% and suspicious washout in 39%.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0033" refid="bib0019"><ce:sup>19</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Histologically, both lesions are seen as fibroelastic cores showing entrapped ducts; the spiculations are explained by their stellate configuration. The term Complex Sclerosing lesion is given to radial scars that are more than 1 cm. Being high-risk precursors of breast carcinoma, image-guided vacuum-assisted biopsy with or without subsequent surgical excision is recommended for these lesions.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0034" refid="bib0017"><ce:sup>17</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref><ce:sup>,</ce:sup><ce:cross-ref id="crf0035" refid="bib0020"><ce:sup>20</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>
</ce:para>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0007">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0009">CONGENITAL</ce:section-title>
<ce:section id="sec0008">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0010">Lymphatic malformation</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0009">Lymphangiomas are congenital lymphatic malformations caused by abnormal rests of lymphatics that do not communicate with the rest of the lymphatic or venous system and proliferate. They are usually observed in children or young adults. Occurrence in the breast is very rare, with fewer than 20 cases reported in the literature.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0036" refid="bib0021"><ce:sup>21</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref><ce:sup>,</ce:sup><ce:cross-ref id="crf0037" refid="bib0022"><ce:sup>22</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> They appear as cystic or multicystic channels without color flow on US and as lobulated masses on MG (<ce:cross-ref id="crf0038" refid="fig0005">Figure 5</ce:cross-ref><ce:float-anchor refid="fig0005"/>). On MRI, they are seen as intercommunicating cystic spaces which are T1 hyperintense (proteinaceous contents) or hypointense, T2 hyperintense with intervening septal enhancement.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0039" refid="bib0023"><ce:sup>23</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> A single layer of endothelium lines these channels, which contain eosinophilic lymphatic fluid and lymphocytes, lymphoid follicles, and sometimes hemorrhagic contents. The most common location is along the axillary tail, and the lesions tend to enlarge over time, even communicating with the skin. Aspiration and fluid analysis or core biopsy can be used to confirm the diagnosis. Treatment options include sclerotherapy and surgical excision.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0040" refid="bib0021"><ce:sup>21</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref><ce:sup>,</ce:sup><ce:cross-ref id="crf0041" refid="bib0022"><ce:sup>22</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>
</ce:para>
</ce:section>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0009">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0011">BENIGN TUMOURS</ce:section-title>
<ce:section id="sec0010">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0012">Atypical or complex fibroadenoma</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0010">Complex fibroadenomas have areas of apocrine metaplasia, epithelial calcifications, sclerosing adenosis, or cysts > 3 mm in addition to the uniform distribution of glandular and stromal elements of a fibroadenoma on histopathology.<ce:sup>24</ce:sup>Although imaging features such as complex echogenicity, irregular shape, non-circumscribed contour, microcalcifications, or posterior acoustic enhancement are more frequently found in complex fibroadenomas than in simple fibroadenomas, imaging cannot reliably distinguish both. When they present as spiculated masses, they may be categorized as BI-RADS 4C lesions. The presence of sclerosing components can cause increased stiffness on elastography.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0042" refid="bib0025"><ce:sup>25</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> The initial incomplete centrifugal enhancement on MRI can also make them appear irregular and suspicious. Nevertheless, the presence of delayed enhancement and non-enhancing internal septations can help in distinguishing them from malignant pathologies<ce:cross-ref id="crf0043" refid="bib0026"><ce:sup>26</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> (<ce:cross-ref id="crf0044" refid="fig0006">Figure 6</ce:cross-ref><ce:float-anchor refid="fig0006"/>). The mean size of complex fibroadenomas is smaller than the simple counterparts, and they are common in older populations, with a higher risk for developing future breast malignancy.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0045" refid="bib0024"><ce:sup>24</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref><ce:sup>,</ce:sup><ce:cross-ref id="crf0046" refid="bib0027"><ce:sup>27</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>
</ce:para>
</ce:section>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0011">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0013">MALIGNANT TUMOURS</ce:section-title>
<ce:section id="sec0012">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0014">Inflammatory breast carcinoma</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0011">Inflammatory breast carcinoma (IBC) accounts for 2 – 5% of all breast cancers. IBC are mostly poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinomas with invasion of the dermal vasculature or lymphatics. It is typically seen in younger patients compared to the locally advanced breast carcinoma. It presents with redness, tenderness, and peau d’orange appearance of the breast (involvement of dermal lymphatics) with rapid progression. Metastasis to the lungs, liver, bone, or brain may be seen in 20 – 40% of cases during the initial presentation itself. Pathologically, most of them have unfavorable subtypes (HER2 positive, triple negative) with factors such as p53 mutation, increased VEGF, increased expression of RhoC, loss of function of WISP3, dysfunction of MUC1 leading to increased tumor invasion, neoangiogenesis, and rapid metastases.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0047" refid="bib0028"><ce:sup>28</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Mammography can show diffuse enlargement of the breast with increased density, coarsened stroma, skin thickening, and enlarged lymph nodes. Ultrasound can reveal increased overall echogenicity of the breast with thickening of the skin and Cooper’s ligament, besides a mass. Dilatation of vessels, invasion of the pectoralis, and involvement of lymph nodes may also be seen.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0048" refid="bib0029"><ce:sup>29</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> In contrary to invasive ductal carcinoma, the presence of inflammatory stroma in breast carcinoma may be associated with pseudo-benign features on elastography.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0049" refid="bib0030"><ce:sup>30</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> MRI can characterize the mass, depict the breast and chest wall edema, and locate abnormal lymph nodes and biopsy targets. A distinct pattern of multiple contiguous enhancing nodules interconnected by non-mass-like enhancement has also been reported in over 50 % of cases.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0050" refid="bib0031"><ce:sup>31</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> The primary differential diagnosis is IGM or any other cause of mastitis, which should be considered over IBC by the presence of abscess or sinus tracts, absence of chest wall extension, and response to antibiotics. However, the final diagnosis is based on biopsy when such differentiating factors are not overtly present. Unilateral breast edema may be observed in congestive cardiac failure on the dependent side due to sleeping on one side. It can also be seen post radiation therapy to the breast, in venous or lymphatic obstructions; however, these cases do not show enhancing masses or significant involvement of the chest wall.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0051" refid="bib0032"><ce:sup>32</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>
</ce:para>
</ce:section>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0013">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0015">Tubular carcinoma</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0012">They are a rare type of invasive breast carcinoma, amounting to about 0.7 to 10.3 % of all breast carcinomas<ce:cross-ref id="crf0052" refid="bib0033"><ce:sup>33</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref><ce:sup>,</ce:sup><ce:cross-ref id="crf0053" refid="bib0034"><ce:sup>34</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>. They are made of ductal epithelium arranged in a tubular pattern with haphazard stromal infiltration, which creates the appearance of a stellate mass with long spicules on MG. (<ce:cross-ref id="crf0054" refid="fig0008">Figure 8</ce:cross-ref>) They have a smaller mean size than the common invasive ductal carcinomas, and most are less than 1 cm. Microcalcifications are uncommon, seen in up to 8 – 24 % of cases, and due to their small size, their appearance can be confused with that of a radial scar. They may also be seen as asymmetry or architectural distortions.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0055" refid="bib0033"><ce:sup>33</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> US can show hypoechoic masses with ill-defined margins and posterior acoustic shadowing.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0056" refid="bib0035"><ce:sup>35</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> While most histological types of breast carcinomas are similarly hard on elastography, tubular carcinomas can show reduced stiffness because of their small size.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0057" refid="bib0036"><ce:sup>36</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> On MRI, they may show high signal intensity and dark internal septations on T2WI.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0058" refid="bib0037"><ce:sup>37</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Rarely, they may also present as non-mass enhancement.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0059" refid="bib0038"><ce:sup>38</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> They can also be associated with concomitant areas of carcinoma in situ or intraductal carcinomas. Nonetheless, pure tubular carcinomas are well-differentiated tumors with a better prognosis than the more common invasive ductal carcinomas.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0060" refid="bib0033"><ce:sup>33</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref><ce:sup>,</ce:sup><ce:cross-ref id="crf0061" refid="bib0035"><ce:sup>35</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> They should not be confused with tubular adenomas, which are benign breast masses pathologically and imaging-wise resembling fibroadenomas, with more epithelial and acinar components than the latter. They may show dense, punctate or irregular microcalcifications (due to inspissated secretions) that are tightly packed within the mass.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0062" refid="bib0039"><ce:sup>39</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>
</ce:para>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0014">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0016">Neuroendocrine carcinoma (NEC)</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0013">These are rare malignancies of the breast with an incidence of less than 1 – 5%. They are slowly growing tumors, and like their counterparts elsewhere in the body, they can cause ectopic hormone production.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0063" refid="bib0040"><ce:sup>40</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> They are considered to arise out of de-differentiation of pre-existing breast carcinoma rather than de novo occurrence, due to the lack of neuroendocrine cells in the breast tissue. Pathologically, NECs are very cellular, showing solid nests or trabeculae of malignant cells with rosette formation or palisading. Immunohistochemical (IHC) testing for neuroendocrine markers such as chromogranin A, synaptophysin, neuron-specific Enolase, or CD56 can confirm the diagnosis.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0064" refid="bib0040"><ce:sup>40</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> While only a handful of cases with imaging appearances have been reported in the literature, their imaging appearance is non-specific, and they have been described as high-density irregular masses with lobulated or spiculated margins (<ce:cross-ref id="crf0065" refid="fig0009">Figure 9</ce:cross-ref>). However, calcifications are uncommon. Like other neuroendocrine tumors, they can also show early and intense enhancement on MRI, and can reach large sizes as compared to invasive carcinomas. As they are very rare in the breast, a CT or PET CT imaging is needed to exclude other sites of primary malignancy.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0066" refid="bib0040"><ce:sup>40</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref><ce:sup>,</ce:sup><ce:cross-ref id="crf0067" refid="bib0041"><ce:sup>41</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>
</ce:para>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0015">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0017">Haemangioendothelioma and angiosarcoma</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0014">Less than 1 percent of breast malignancies are sarcomas. One of them includes angiosarcoma, which is usually observed in patients post-radiation therapy or with chronic lymphedema. They are aggressive lesions and may present with synchronous distant metastases, particularly in younger patients.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0068" refid="bib0042"><ce:sup>42</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Haemangioendothelioma is also a malignancy of vascular epithelial origin, but with borderline malignant potential. It can be associated with Kasabach-Meritt syndrome, where it commonly occurs in the retroperitoneum or extremity. Very few reports of breast hemangioendotheliomas are available in the literature.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0069" refid="bib0043"><ce:sup>43</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref><ce:sup>,</ce:sup><ce:cross-ref id="crf0070" refid="bib0044"><ce:sup>44</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> MG can show asymmetry or masses, and US can show tubular irregular channels representing blood-filled spaces with surrounding vascularity. <ce:cross-ref id="crf0071" refid="bib0043"><ce:sup>43</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref><ce:sup>,</ce:sup><ce:cross-ref id="crf0072" refid="bib0044"><ce:sup>44</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> They can show markedly high signals in T2WI on MRI with delayed progressive enhancement due to the blood-filled spaces and channels.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0073" refid="bib0045"><ce:sup>45</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> The mass in the illustrated patient (<ce:cross-ref id="crf0074" refid="fig0010">Figure 10</ce:cross-ref>) showed intermediate to hard stiffness on elastography, correlating with their counterparts in the liver described in the literature.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0075" refid="bib0046"><ce:sup>46</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Histologically, these masses are comprised of eosinophilic spindle-shaped cells, which have single large nuclei showing vesicular chromatin, varying nuclear pleomorphism depending on the grade. These cells are arranged as cords or nests of cells surrounding areas of hemorrhage called ‘blood lakes’, and contain immature ramifying vascular channels which may sometimes connect with capillaries of the skin.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0076" refid="bib0045"><ce:sup>45</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>
</ce:para>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0016">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0018">MISCELLANEOUS</ce:section-title>
<ce:section id="sec0017">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0019">Hyperprolactinemia-induced breast changes</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0015">Galactoceles are the most common benign breast disease during lactation. They can be completely radiolucent, show fat–fluid levels, or show a pseudo-hamartoma- or pseudolipoma-like appearance on MG. Ultrasound depicts complicated cysts with internal moving echoes.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0077" refid="bib0047"><ce:sup>47</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> They may also appear as complex cysts with septations, and color Doppler is needed to rule out any vascularity within. Aspiration of the milky contents showed chalky amorphous or crystalline material on cytology. A diagnosis of galactocele in non-puerperal women is infrequent. It has been reported to be due to underlying hyperprolactinemia, which can be drug-related (antipsychotics) or due to pituitary lesions.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0078" refid="bib0048"><ce:sup>48</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref><ce:sup>,</ce:sup><ce:cross-ref id="crf0079" refid="bib0048"><ce:sup>48</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref><ce:sup>,</ce:sup><ce:cross-ref id="crf0080" refid="bib0049"><ce:sup>49</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Although they resolve on their own once the hormonal cause is corrected, those with secondary infection and mastitis need drainage and treatment with appropriate antibiotics. Hyperprolactinemia, by being proinflammatory and enhancing milk production, can also result in duct ectasia, galactorrhea, fibrocystic changes, and idiopathic granulomatous mastitis<ce:cross-ref id="crf0081" refid="bib0048"><ce:sup>48</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> (<ce:cross-ref id="crf0082" refid="fig0011">Figure 11</ce:cross-ref>).</ce:para>
</ce:section>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0018">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0020">Parasitic infection</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0016">Parasitic infections of the breast, such as filariasis, cysticercosis, and dracunculosis, have been reported in endemic areas. Cysticercosis can be seen on ultrasound as well-defined cysts with echogenic nodules near the wall, loculations of fluid with internal echoes, irregular cysts with extruded scolex, or peripherally calcified cysts (<ce:cross-ref id="crf0083" refid="fig0012">Figure 12</ce:cross-ref>). MG can show the calcified scolex.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0084" refid="bib0050"><ce:sup>50</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> MRI can show a T2 hyperintense cyst with eccentric T2 hypointense scolex and surrounding edema in the active stages. Fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) may show larval fragments, hooklets, or calcified corpuscles, while the scolex is not routinely seen. A histopathological confirmation after surgical excision may be needed if parasites are not visualized by FNAC.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0085" refid="bib0051"><ce:sup>51</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> On the other hand, filariasis of the breast can present as serpiginous calcifications on MG and tubular cystic structures due to dilated lymphatics on US with demonstration of the ‘Filarial dance’ sign, which is a color motion artifact due to the swirling movement of filarial larvae.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0086" refid="bib0052"><ce:sup>52</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> A cytological examination of the fluid aspirate, as well as blood samples by finger prick, can depict microfilariae to confirm the diagnosis. Old sequel of the eradicated dracunculiasis can appear as linear serpiginous areas of calcification on mammogram and can mimic ductal calcifications, prior mastitis sequela or calcified sutures.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0087" refid="bib0053"><ce:sup>53</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>
</ce:para>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0019">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0021">Asymmetric breast uptake on Fluorine-18 Fluorodeoxyglucose Positron Emission Tomography (18–F FDG PET)</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0017">Normal breasts show homogeneous symmetric uptake on PET with SUVmax values less than 2.5. The uptake is higher in younger females with increased breast density and during the ovulation and secretory phase.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0088" refid="bib0054"><ce:sup>54</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Asymmetric uptake can be physiological, due to differential response to hormonal stimulation, single breast lactation, or can be due to pathological causes such as masses, mastitis, and edema. Lactating breasts show breast enlargement with cord- or mass-like hyperattenuating tissue on CT. There is increased glucose transporter (GLUT 1) expression in the lactating breast, which causes increased FDG uptake (<ce:cross-ref id="crf0089" refid="fig0013">Figure 13</ce:cross-ref>). Preferentially, single breast lactation can lead to asymmetric uptake, which can be confused with inflammatory breast carcinoma (IBC). Detection of breast malignancies in lactating breasts also becomes difficult due to the physiologically increased uptake.<ce:cross-ref id="crf0090" refid="bib0055"><ce:sup>55</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref> Breast malignancies like IBC, lymphoma, and lymphangitic metastases can all present with unilateral breast edema<ce:cross-ref id="crf0091" refid="bib0032"><ce:sup>32</ce:sup></ce:cross-ref>. Asymmetric FDG uptake with breast enlargement can also be due to causes outside the breast, such as congestive cardiac failure (dependent side), lymphatic or venous obstruction, or as a complication of arteriovenous dialysis fistula. Although an appropriate clinical history and negative imaging findings can rule out malignancy, histopathological confirmation may be required in ambiguous cases.(<ce:cross-ref id="crf0092" refid="tbl0001">Table 1</ce:cross-ref><ce:float-anchor refid="tbl0001"/>
<Query/>)</ce:para>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0020" role="conclusion">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0022">CONCLUSION</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0018">A definitive diagnosis for unusual breast lesions may not be possible from imaging alone due to the non-specific imaging features of many pathologies, and histopathological diagnosis has become the gold standard. However, knowledge of the known imaging appearances along with clinical, epidemiological, and pathological correlations can aid in faster and appropriate clinical management. Adequate auditing of the pathological results, checking for concordance, and multidisciplinary discussions of discordant reports are crucial for accurate diagnosis and management of patients.(<ce:cross-ref id="crf0093" refid="fig0007">Figure 7</ce:cross-ref><ce:float-anchor refid="fig0007"/><ce:float-anchor refid="fig0008"/><ce:float-anchor refid="fig0009"/><ce:float-anchor refid="fig0010"/><ce:float-anchor refid="fig0011"/><ce:float-anchor refid="fig0012"/><ce:float-anchor refid="fig0013"/><?Qry msg="CE dummy citation of figure 7 and table 1 is inserted.please check"?>)</ce:para>
</ce:section>
<ce:section id="sec0021" role="funding">
<ce:section-title id="cesectitle0023">Sources of funding</ce:section-title>
<ce:para id="para0019">None</ce:para>
</ce:section>
</ce:sections>
